comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: The history of Clerys began in May 1853 when Mc Swiney, Delany and Co. opened ‘The New or Palatial Mart' on the site of the present store in what was then Sackville Street. In 1883, the premises was taken over and renamed by M. J. Clery (d.1896) So After 1896 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clerys

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Hawksby's didn't advertise in Freeman's themselves, but F.W. Hawksby is listed in 1883 (28rd April) as a stockist of McMahon and Twohils' Irish-made silk and fur hats. Or, as the advertisement put it - "HATS!  HATS!! HATS!!!"

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Yep pre-1911. No sign of Parnell Monument.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Ah, for the days of simpler advertising, when you just called a spade a spade... And Aha! Hawksby Hats led to this in the Irish Times classifieds on Saturday, 22 February 1908
RETIRING from Business - High Class Goods, much under cost price: Gents' Shirts, 1s 1/2d: Ties from 1 1/2d. - Hawksby, 28 Upper Sackville street.
So [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] 1896-early 1908 then...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: 25 Upper Sackville Street. This was being built in 1883. Gregory Sheils, photographer, was there in 1891, 1894, 1896. In 1901 Gregory Sheils, photographer, 67, was living at 4 Rutland St Upper with his wife and two daughters, 14 and 21: both girls were photographers www.irisharchaeology.info/genealogy/photographers.html

comment.author: 32162360@N00

That is not how I read it in this bit of the Archiseek discussion - www.archiseek.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=49&t=2087&... - "Our friends at the northern end appear to have been used simply as a protective feature around a three-arm lamp standard (as featured here before), long since disappeared, located in the vast untamed environment of Upper Sackville/Great Britain streets." ,,, and then an old photo of the front of that round theatre - img.photobucket.com/albums/v219/Dublin1/UpperSackvilleStR...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003762099/ Hawksby living in Sackville Street in 1901 Susan A is a draper and a widow 32y and her daughter Kathleen 14y and also a draper. Could possibly be the same people in 1911 - no profession noted but Susan Annie is now 51 and Kate Ringwood is 27???? www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai000035519/ Perhaps not????

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] The Bollards ARE there, but just out of frame to the left, OR INSIDE that 'coffee booth'. See comeheretome.com/2011/03/15/coffee-booth-on-oconnell-street/ (originally posted by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] at www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/6509876797/ ). That photo shows a shorter "coffee booth", the bollards surrounding a very ornate gas lamp. and the electric pylon for the tramway, so not too distant in time from this photo.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] I'm not sure the Parnell Monument would be in the frame in this photo. The 1907 OS Map shows a structure which corresponds to the "Coffee and Refreshment Booth". The monument would be further north of this.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: That photo on comeheretome is an interesting one for comparison. The tramwires are visible, so after 1899, but the lights are the tall pre-1903 items, not the swan necked ones, and best of all, the facade of the Gresham is completely different! That huge GRESHAM at roof level is added between the two. The DIA lists work done in 1904 and in 1907-8, but doesn't mention the facade.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Rats, here is one in the archive with the tall lights and the newer facade, so the facade does not help with dating this one, it predates the swan-necked lamps. Here is an older shot of the facade, no electric lights at all. Mr. Mackey is next door back then, too.

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content:
Weren't the square bases removed from some of the streetlights in 1904 if I recall correctly? It happened around Nassau street then.

Incidentally the tram on the left, no.112, was a conversion to electric from a horse drawn one, converted in 1900. 
The lack of cars on the street, even post 1903, isn't all that surprising, bob Montgomery in "An Irish Roadside Camera" has a photo of Sackville street from 1903 which shows only trams and horse drawn carts
